subject: adding connectors
messageBody:
Chuck:

I have been using QS since 1974.  In my opinion, the alphabet was designed in such a way that many letters naturally connect to other letters because they end where other letters begin.  Off the top of my head, the only use of a connector I can think of that is authorized by the QS manual is the addition of a connecting line back up to the base line after writing the deep TH letter.  That seems permissible because it cannot be confused with any other letter.  I believe Kingsley Read's intention was that where letters can be joined without connectors they should be joined, but connectors should not be added between other letters where their use would be likely to cause difficulties in reading the text.  The idea is that legibility should not be sacrificed for the slight increase in writing speed for letters which do not connect naturally and require an alteration in the form of the letter.  Therefore, I believe your suggestion is inadvisable.

Another example of the confusion this leads to are the debates I have had with people who learned to write in the 70s.  My step-daughter believes that the roman letter "m" has three humps and an "n" has two because she confuses the connector which she was taught to write before the letter with part of the letter.  When she writes a lower case "m" at the beginning of a word, she still starts with a connector from the base line before writing the letter.  Obviously, her teachers never corrected this error.  We want to avoid this sort of confusion with QS.

Paige Gabhart

Chuck Peck wrote:
Hello All,

I use Quickscript almost %100 in my personal writings
and I’ve found one thing that prevents me from using
it in a fully scripted mode.

There are 2 characters that prevent Quickscript from
being fully scripted, the #28 as in “Ed” and the #30
as in “Ash”. When trying to connect one letter to the
next many times I find I could use and upward or
downward curving line to complete the connection.
Unfortunately the letters #28 & #30 currently uses
these two shapes. 

A possible solution for this would be to modify the
#28 & #30 characters to make them distinct from a
connecting stroke. The attached pictures are examples
of a possible modification to them that might help.

Please let me know your comments and thoughts about
this.

Chuck

  I have been using QS since 1974.  In my opinion, the alphabet was designed

be sacrificed for the slight increase in writing speed for letters which

 Therefore, I believe your suggestion is inadvisable.<br>
  <br>
  Another example of the confusion this leads to are the debates I have had
